channel.title: covid on Environment & Health Data Portal
channel.description: Recent content in covid on Environment & Health Data Portal

item.title: An update on air quality during COVID-19
item.description: Big improvements in outdoor air quality during COVID-19 reveal impacts of traffic and commercial cooking On March 20, 2020, New York State announced the COVID-19 shutdown, officially known as NY Pause. In NYC, it lasted until June 8, 2020. With stay-at-home orders in NY and other states, New York City’s air quality changed significantly. Earlier, we looked at data collected from real-time air pollution monitors to see how day-to-day pollution changed when people started to stay home.

item.title: Air quality during COVID-19
item.description: What happens when NYC stays home? The COVID-19 pandemic upended the lives of all New Yorkers. The outbreak has affected many aspects of our daily life, but there are also less apparent effects, such as impacts on our environment. The NYC Community Air Survey uses air quality monitors to take hourly measurements of fine particulate (PM2.5) at a few sites around the city. Generally, locations around the city see changes in PM2.
